resources.string: English mathematician, has made significant contributions to finite groups, knot theory, number theory, combinatorial game theory, and coding theory. Notably, he is known for inventing the cellular automaton called the Game of Life in recreational mathematics

The **Game of Life**, also known simply as "Life," is a cellular automaton developed in 1970. It is a zero-player game, indicating that its evolution is solely determined by its initial state and does not necessitate additional actions. Players engage with the Game of Life by creating an initial configuration and observing its development. Notably, it is Turing complete, allowing it to model a universal constructor or any other Turing machine. 

## Universe Description 

The universe of the Game of Life is an infinite, two-dimensional orthogonal grid consisting of square cells. Each cell can exist in one of two states: live or dead (or populated and unpopulated, respectively). Interaction takes place between each cell and its eight neighbors, encompassing cells that are horizontally, vertically, or diagonally adjacent. 

## Evolution Rules 

At each step in time, the following transitions occur: 

- Any live cell with fewer than two live neighbors dies, as if by underpopulation. 

- Any live cell with two or three live neighbors lives on to the next generation. 

- Any live cell with more than three live neighbors dies, as if by overpopulation. 

- Any dead cell with exactly three live neighbors becomes a live cell, as if by reproduction.
Devised this simulation of cellular automata evolution in 1970, called the \"Game of Life\", where each cell on the game field follows simple rules
In an empty (dead) cell, if there are exactly three living neighbors, life is born
If a living cell has two or three living neighbors, it continues to live; otherwise, the cell dies (due to "loneliness" or "overcrowding")
